nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based evaluation causes lasting improvements in teacher effectiveness by improving teacher skill, effort, or both

Cincinnati's Teacher Evaluation System (TES) provides individualized, micro-level feedback through rubric-scored peer and administrator observations that could supply new information to teachers about their practice

Quasi-experimental, teacher fixed effects design exploiting phased-in scheduled evaluation years for veteran mid-career 4th–8th grade math teachers, comparing within-teacher performance before, during, and after TES
Analysis sample: mid-career math teachers hired 1993–1999, evaluated 2003–2010; sample includes 105 teachers and 14,331 student-year observations with matched baseline and outcome test scores

TES evaluation procedure: year-long cycle with three peer observations and one administrator observation, rubric based on Danielson framework, written feedback and at least one feedback meeting, final summative scores in four domains

Main empirical result: students taught after their teacher's TES evaluation score about 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than similar students taught by the same teacher before evaluation; students during evaluation score about 0.052 SD higher (less precisely estimated)
Reading achievement shows no statistically significant gains associated with TES evaluation in the same specifications
Event-study evidence: no clear preexisting upward trend in teacher performance in years prior to evaluation, supporting the before/during/after parameterization

Heterogeneous effects: postevaluation gains are largest for teachers with low pre-TES value-added, low TES scores, and those whose TES scores rose most during the TES year; specialized math teachers show larger gains than self-contained teachers

Robustness checks: results robust to alternative experience controls, omission of covariates, use of scheduled-phase-in timing as instrument (2SLS), event-study specification, and attrition-weighted and balanced-sample analyses

Identification assumption: timing of TES evaluation is unrelated to unobserved, time-varying student assignment or preexisting teacher-specific performance trends after conditioning on teacher fixed effects, student covariates, prior achievement, and experience controls

Limitations: data do not identify the exact behavioral mechanisms driving gains, results may be specific to mid-career teachers receiving infrequent evaluations and to a peer-evaluator model, and some attrition remains a concern though checks mitigate bias

Conclusion: Well-structured, subjective classroom observation evaluation can produce nontransient increases in teacher effectiveness and function as an effective form of professional development beyond selective dismissal or short-run incentives
